content:
The "Medicare Commission Act of 1996" is established. The National Commission on the Long-Term Solvency of the Medicare Program is established with 15 members appointed by the President and Senate leaders. The National Commission on the Long-Term Solvency of the Medicare Program consists of 15 members appointed by the President and Senate leaders. Five members are appointed by the Majority Leader of the Senate, not more than 3 from the same political party, and not more than 2 from Congress. Five members are appointed by the Speaker of the House of Representatives, following similar guidelines. The House of Representatives, in consultation with the Minority Leader, appoints members to the Commission on the Long-Term Solvency of the Medicare Program. The appointments must be made within 3 months of the Act's enactment, and members serve for the life of the Commission with vacancies filled promptly. The Commission on the Long-Term Solvency of the Medicare Program members are appointed for life, vacancies do not affect its powers, and meetings are held as needed with a majority of members constituting a quorum. The Commission selects a Chairman from among its members. The Commission on the Long-Term Solvency of the Medicare Program appoints members for life, holds meetings as needed, and selects a Chairman from among its members. The Commission on the Long-Term Solvency of the Medicare Program reviews analyses of the financial condition of the Medicare trust funds, identifies potential problems, and analyzes solutions to ensure financial integrity and provision of health benefits. The Commission on the Long-Term Solvency of the Medicare Program reviews the financial condition of the Medicare trust funds and provides recommendations to preserve their long-term solvency. The Medicare trust funds refer to the Federal Hospital Insurance Trust Fund established under the Social Security Act. The Commission on the Long-Term Solvency of the Medicare Program reviews the financial condition of the Medicare trust funds and provides recommendations to preserve their long-term solvency. The Commission shall submit its report to the President and Congress within 12 months of its first meeting. Congressional leaders will introduce legislation based on the Commission's recommendations. The Majority Leader of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives, in consultation with the Minority Leaders, will develop legislation within 3 months to ensure the long-term solvency of the Medicare trust funds. Legislation in the Senate and House of Representatives aims to ensure the long-term solvency of the Medicare trust funds, with privileged consideration if not voted upon within 3 months. Legislation introduced in the House or Senate will be given privileged consideration if not voted upon within 3 months. Committees in the House will be discharged from considering the legislation, and a motion to proceed to its consideration will be highly privileged in the House. Legislation introduced in the Senate will be treated as highly privileged if not voted upon within 3 months. Committees in the Senate will be discharged from considering the legislation. Legislation introduced in the Senate will be treated as highly privileged if not voted upon within 3 months. Committees will be discharged from considering the legislation, and a motion to proceed to its consideration in the Senate will be treated as privileged. If the legislation is not voted on within 3 months, a vote on endorsing commission recommendations will be required. If legislation introduced in the Senate is not voted on within 3 months, it becomes highly privileged. A motion to consider a joint resolution endorsing commission recommendations must then be made. SEC. 4. POWERS OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, and utilize postal services as needed to fulfill the requirements of this Act. The Commission has the authority to utilize postal services like other federal agencies. SEC. 5. COMMISSION PERSONNEL MATTERS. Members of the Commission who are federal government officers or employees serve without additional compensation. Private citizens on the Commission also serve without pay. Members of the Commission who are not federal government officers or employees receive travel expenses for their work, including per diem, at rates authorized for agency employees under title 5, United States Code. The Chairman of the Commission has the authority to appoint an executive director and additional personnel without following civil service laws. The Secretary of Health and Human Services can provide administrative and support services as needed. The Chairman of the Commission has the authority to appoint an executive director and other personnel, with the executive director's compensation determined by the Chairman without following certain pay regulations. The Chairman of the Commission has the authority to appoint an executive director and other personnel, with the rate of pay not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement, and temporary services can be procured at specified rates. The Chairman of the Commission can appoint personnel at rates not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule for services under section 3109(b) of title 5, United States Code. SEC. 6. TERMINATION OF THE COMMISSION: The Commission will end 30 days after submitting its report. 

SEC. 7. FUNDING FOR THE COMMISSION: The Commission's expenses will be covered by funds available to the Secretary of Health and Human Services.
